description: Dans une ancienne usine de chaussures, la cheffe Alice Arnoux officie dans ce bistrot au style loft industriel épuré. Ouvert du matin au soir, on y mange, prend un café ou un verre. La carte est simple : le soir, un menu dégustation sans choix ; le midi, un menu-carte avec deux options reprenant les plats du soir. Seiche grillée, fenouil nouveau et tapenade verte ; veau fermier, asperges glacées, moutarde fermentée : chaque plat, à base de produits frais, est dynamisé par un détail gourmand.

Karl-Louis Kömmler, an ambitious chef who also happens to be self-taught, is at work in this small restaurant in Kreuzberg. He has the support of a professional and highly motivated young team, who clearly enjoy being part of the pared-back modern dining concept here. The food breaks with culinary conventions – based on the classics, it is strongly influenced by Japanese cuisine – and when it comes to the quality of the ingredients, no compromises are made. The menu comprises eight courses, in addition to specials that can be added on as an upgrade. In the veal sweetbread, they have a true signature dish: finely seasoned, crispy on the outside and creamy-tender on the inside, it is served with N25 Kaluga caviar and habanero sauce, which give the dish a pleasing kick with their brininess and wonderful heat – all in perfect harmony. It is powerful, pared down and original. The wine list may be on the short side, but it features a good selection. The front-of-house team is charming and highly knowledgeable, and the chefs themselves serve and explain the dishes. The minimalist interior is inviting. Seats are spread over two levels, with some at the counter, from which there is a view of the open kitchen. There is a small covered terrace in front of this corner building.

This small but charming restaurant in the Justicia neighbourhood is the Madrid offshoot of Corsario (located inside the Ibizan hotel La Torre del Canónigo). It dazzles both for its elegant décor and its carefully crafted cuisine, as young Cuban chef Liván Valdés serves up a Mediterranean-based cuisine that plays with local flavours and those of the Madrid mountains, skilfully combining them with other more international influences.

This spacious venue, which is not without a certain magnetism, is spread over two floors (the semi-basement houses Atelier, chef Ramón Freixa's unique gastronomic space). It offers a surprisingly elegant, bourgeois atmosphere, with an abundance of wood, carefully chosen vintage details, a space dedicated to cured meats (complete with a ham carver), ample wine cellar, and a bar serving classic cocktails. Flavour reigns supreme here, which is why they offer a traditional yet refreshingly modern menu that draws on Catalan cuisine, drawing inspiration from family recipes. Make sure to try the aged rum baba with whipped cream for dessert!

Typical Roman dishes made from carefully selected ingredients grace the menu of this restaurant, which is housed in a grain storehouse that once belonged to the neighbouring Papal State. Large paintings by contemporary artists hang on the walls and there is a small lounge with a fireplace near the entrance.

A historic palazzo built over the foundations of the Teatro Pompeo is home to this atmospheric restaurant, which brings together history and contemporary art. However, the real star is the fish on the menu, most of which comes from the island of Ponza, and is served either raw or cooked very simply in a modern style.

adresse: Rua Marquês de Fronteira, Lisbonne, 1070-051, Portugal
description: An exclusive dining space, occupying a building with a minimalist designer feel in the upper section of the Amália Rodrigues gardens, with stunning views of the Eduardo VII park. Within this context, German chef Joachim Koerper, who has over five decades of experience behind him, conjures up Mediterranean-inspired cuisine with a meticulous and creative touch, based around locally sourced seasonal ingredients. His culinary focus is built around four menus: the “20 years of the Eleven restaurant”, featuring dishes that have marked his career in the different countries he has worked; a seasonal menu; a vegetarian option; and, lastly, the “Lavagante Azul”, which showcases the blue lobster after which it is named. À la carte options are also available. You can’t go wrong whatever you choose, especially with the chef’s signature dishes such as “My day in Singapore’s food market”, prepared with lacquered suckling pig, fried rice, mango and shrimp, or the cassoulet of white asparagus served with teardrop peas and caviar.

adresse: Estrada da Lagoa Azul, Sintra, 2714-511, Portugal
description: Open since 1992, this Japanese restaurant is one of the country’s oldest. Its connection to Japanese culture is clear, as Midori means “green”, an obvious reference to the fantastic vegetation surrounding the Penha Longa hotel, merging into the lush mountains of the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park. An open kitchen, vinyl-covered walls, a beautiful mural designed by a Portuguese artist, and large windows are the backdrop for a pleasant, cosy atmosphere. The offering of talented Chef Pedro Almeida, here served up daily by the young resident chef Tiago Santo, reveals Portuguese cuisine with a Japanese soul, adopting the techniques of the Far East country and applying them to the best local produce. Across two tasting menus — Kiri and Yama, with 7 and 9 courses, respectively — the selection translates into bold dishes like the roasted tomato nigiri, the Kakuni-style beef tongue served with scorched aubergine and tomato, or the surprising dessert of Hachi (honey and oats).

The culinary concept behind 100 Maneiras is one of absolute freedom – one that constantly takes risks and seeks to provoke a strong reaction and to leave a lasting mark with guests, often via ingredients referred to as "from the future" or that are little known. Everything here revolves around chef Ljubomir Stanisic, a native of Sarajevo (Bosnia-Herzegovina), who arrived in Portugal in his late-teens following the war in his country, healing the wounds of his soul by devoting himself to cooking. His different tasting menus The Story, Echoes of 100 (vegetarian) and Lunch Short Story (served exclusively for lunch on Fridays and Saturdays), are based around innovative cuisine with a constant nod (both physical and emotional) to his origins, although influences from his adopted homeland and further afield are also evident. His more traditional starters and desserts also have an interesting twist given that he used to make these with his mother!

Undoubtedly a classic! This restaurant is a sure bet for anyone wanting to guarantee a quality meal. Set by the sea on the Estrada do Guincho, the building retains its classic nautical lines, with décor that harmoniously blends wood and light tones. The region’s fish and seafood are naturally the highlight, with traditional dishes such as Bulhão Pato clams, Galician-style octopus and the flavoursome fish-and-seafood cataplana taking centre stage… Alongside the à la carte dishes there are sharing menus for two (Mariscada, Do Mar and Porto de Santa Maria) – and do not hesitate to visit the impressive wine cellar: it is truly a hidden treasure!

If you’ve never eaten lunch or dinner 120m above ground, you might want to enjoy the experience in this unique dining space in the famous Vasco da Gama tower that dominates Lisbon’s skyline, with its impressive views of the city, the Tagus, and even the magical Troia peninsula (access is via a panoramic lift that takes exactly 50 seconds to reach the top, hence the name of the restaurant). At the helm is Rui Silvestre, a chef with an extensive career working in renowned restaurants and famous for being the youngest chef in Portugal to hold a coveted Michelin star. His cooking is showcased on a single menu entitled “Fauna and Flora” (10, 12 or 14 courses) that is full of surprises thanks to its incomparable flavours and use of local ingredients, as well as spices and citrus notes that result in superb combinations. A good example is his Octopus and beet dish, served with two sauces (yogurt and herbs and another with massala), accompanied by "nan" bread made with garlic butter.

adresse: Rua da Bela Vista à Graça 126, Lisbonne, 1170-075, Portugal
description: Trás-os-Montes-born chef Vítor Adão’s roots are strongly anchored in tradition and the provenance of his ingredients. Having worked in several leading restaurants, he decided to open his own eatery where he showcases the heritage of his native region. His cooking is based around two surprise tasting menus (7 and 10 courses) that vary according to what is available from producers. Despite its simple decoration, enhanced by numerous jars of pickles to highlight the connection with the land, the overall feel here is elegant. The pleasant terrace is perfect for outdoor dining in warmer weather.

adresse: Largo da Academia Nacional de Belas Artes 14, Lisbonne, 1200-005, Portugal
description: A culinary enclave well worth considering in the historic Chiado district, which toys with Newton’s law of universal gravitation to create its own "Gravitational Taste" concept. Here, behind the robust façade of an old building, you’ll find an informal, more modern interior that includes an open-view kitchen and dining rooms lit in a contemporary, minimalist fashion. Enjoy superb views across the Tagus estuary to a backdrop of geometrically shaped ceilings and azulejo panels which are a silent testament to the past but which add appropriate character and personality. The creative cooking on display is highly visual yet at the same time elegant, pure and with a strong focus on vegetables. French chef Vincent Farges follows the thinking of Leonardo da Vinci in his defence of "simplicity and maximum sophistication", focusing on the essentials to elevate the dining experience via two tasting menus: Inspirações (8 courses) and Epurismo (10 courses).

It is installed on the ground floor with an entrance independent from the luxurious hotel Verride Palácio de Santa Catarina — an elegant eighteenth‑century palace. At the head of the kitchen is chef Fábio Alves, from Trás‑os‑Montes, who seeks to recall recipes from his native region through authentic flavours and aromas — as in the starters served in a glass box, with small snacks of Alheira (smoked bread‑and‑meat sausage), bacalhau (salt‑cod), tomato, broa (cornbread), folar (Easter loaf) and azeitona (olive). However, the menu does not forget dishes from the rest of the country, nor the magnificent fish from the Portuguese coast, such as the appealing course comprising Atlantic fish, millet and razor clam. The offering, presented with a modern touch, is composed of three tasting menus (Full Experience, 5 or 4 courses) and a reduced à la carte menu with vegetarian options. At the end, go up to the incredible panoramic terrace and enjoy 360º views over the beautiful city of Lisbon. But note if you wish to go as a family, as only children aged 12 and over are accepted!

Chef João Rodrigues’s concept, located in a residential area, harks back to the neighbourhood restaurants of the past, yet retains the essence of a bistro. Sitting at the counter and watching the kitchen bustle contributes to a relaxed and vibrant atmosphere. Here, the focus is on the products — displayed in a showcase at the entrance — prepared simply, offered at accessible prices, and presented in a sharing format. A blackboard displays the daily lunch specials and, in addition, an appealing menu. Whether it’s the succulent open prawn omelette with onion, the iconic squid dish with sheep’s butter, or the simple yet authentic peach served with eggnog and creamy pistachio ice cream, one thing is certain — it does not disappoint!

This spot is somewhat hidden away in the Alcântara district, and its name bears a certain mysticism; not without reason, as it alludes to the four elements of nature (Earth, Water, Fire and Air). Brazilian chef Habner Gomes, well supported by José Balau as dining room director and sommelier, offers a Japanese-inspired proposal in the kaiseki style, presenting a single omakase tasting menu that reveals extensive expertise and extreme refinement, as the dishes are plated with the utmost attention to detail. It features a comfortable sushi counter for ten diners, and goes beyond the usual raw cuisine to introduce us to Japan’s hot dishes, with tasty broths and grilled preparations. Curious details? The dishes, which always celebrate fish from the Portuguese coast (seabream, Atlantic leerfish, eel, Azorean bonito, etc.), take their names from the techniques used (Sakizuke [appetiser], Otsukuri [sliced raw fish], Niguirizushi [hand-formed sushi], Agemono [deep-fried dish], etc.).

adresse: piazza Trinità dei Monti 6, Rome, 00187, Italie
description: The location of this rooftop restaurant could hardly be more glamorous. Head up the most famous flight of steps in the world to the Hassler hotel, where you take a lift up to one of the Italian capital’s most celebrated restaurants. Here, you dine surrounded by floor-to-ceiling windows that offer superb views of Rome, from the twin bell towers of Trinità dei Monti church to a whole host of the city’s iconic monuments – see how many you can recognise! In the meantime, chef Andrea Antonini prepares two tasting menus that showcase his classic dishes alongside more recent creations. His cuisine is often based on recognised recipes and ingredients, while also exploring new ideas, unusual combinations and amusing reinterpretations.

Situated in Tivoli’s historic centre, this restaurant has a young chef at the helm who skilfully pays tribute to the region’s gastronomic traditions. Although the menu also features a few fish dishes and the occasional ingredient from outside Lazio, it is the dishes made from local produce with their intense, delicious flavours that will linger long in the memory.

If you’re looking for a restaurant with innovative dishes and excellent value for money, you’re in the right place. The setting is pleasant, well cared for, and features a minimalist design. Most tables offer a direct view of the open kitchen, allowing guests to watch the chefs at work. A vegetarian menu with paired wines is also available. Service is always friendly and attentive, making the dining experience even more enjoyable.

This restaurant is part of one of the best food outlets in Rome, which offers delicacies such as typical Roman pastas, cooked and raw fish, meat, an impressive selection of cured hams and cheeses, as well as top-quality ingredients such as anchovies and mozzarella. Excellent home-baked bread and a varied wine list complete the picture. Make sure you book ahead, as it’s hard to get a table here without a reservation.

Two smart dining rooms offer two different dining experiences at this restaurant: one with chairs at the bar and a conveyer belt of traditional Japanese dishes; the other serving contemporary Japanese cuisine, including the intriguing Omakase tasting menu. Nearly all the wines and sakes on the wine list are also available by the glass.

In a charming medieval palace, a spiral staircase leads to an elegant dining room where Liberty-style cement tiles and chestnut tables tell stories of taste and tradition. Here comes to life the restaurant led by talented Gian Marco Bianchi, with his motto: new rural cuisine. Prepare for a culinary journey that reinvents the flavors of the land with a contemporary touch. Choose between a tasting menu or a four-course experience, where the shepherd’s raviolo with sheep’s ricotta and lamb jus captivates with its intensity, while the grilled lamb with “cacio e ovo,” a zabaglione served alongside, is pure poetry to savor. The perfect toast? A local sparkling wine: malvasia with a touch of sangiovese, traditional method aged 36 months on the lees. A sparkling start to an unforgettable experience!

This restaurant with a simple dining room and open-view kitchen serves some of the most interesting fish cuisine in the Della Vittoria district. Chef Federico Delmonte skilfully searches out “poor” varieties of fish which are nonetheless full of flavour on an open menu that is adjusted according to the catch of the day. The chef’s native Fano makes an appearance in a few recipes from the Marche, including the famous brodetto (a typical fish soup).

Housed in a 17C palazzo just a stone’s throw from the Piazza del Popolo, this restaurant run by Alain Ducasse, the chef with the most Michelin stars worldwide, is part of the Romeo hotel. The dining room, designed by architect Zaha Hadid, is panelled in ebony, while the open-view kitchen is in marble – luxury certainly takes centre stage here. The cuisine is on a par with the exquisite decor, featuring top-quality ingredients which young Jacopo Iualè transforms into dishes with a Mediterranean flavour.

adresse: Mira el Río Baja, 20, Madrid, 28005, Espagne
description: Under this name, which nods to the Japanese art of binding and could be translated as ‘bond’, we find a humble and informal restaurant that specialises in Japanese grilling and showcases robata cooking as its hallmark. They offer an à la carte service, but we recommend the Omakase menu, as it takes you on a varied journey through their most significant dishes, such as the snow crab Monaka with smoked baby eel or their tasty brioche with prawns cooked on the robata, lightly seasoned with seven Japanese spices.

If you enjoy Japanese cuisine, this is one of those places that is a must given its focus on presentation and the innovative touch that they add to its dishes (over 35 different courses). Chef Steven Wu, who trained in restaurants in both Tokyo and Kyoto, offers guests his surprise Omakase menu which is the only option here. His Kaiseki-style cooking places full emphasis on the seasonality of ingredients and a respect for tradition, replicating the five types of time-honoured preparation and cooking methods to ensure the perfect harmony between visual and tasting sensations. The immersive experience here develops in four different spaces, each with its own personality: the reception area (the garden-style corridor, where the aim is to recreate the different seasons of the year), a splendid Japanese dining counter, the tea room (where an ancestral ceremony takes place), and the cocktail bar, with its Japanese pop music, where you have the option of rounding off your meal with a choice of whiskies and cocktails.

The first thing you notice at this restaurant, located in the city’s Chamberí district, and which describes itself as “a playful space with a minimal-intervention mentality”, is its eclectic and industrial look, which is dominated by large wooden beams and open brick walls. The French chef at the helm, Alice Reydet, was trained in leading restaurants and now focuses on commonsense cooking combining French and Mediterranean influences that is contemporary in style but with lots of personality, and incorporates seasonal ingredients and the flavours of traditional cuisine. The à la carte, featuring interesting dishes designed for sharing (such as sea urchin, brioche, salted butter; sea bass, citrus, piparra peppers; and sweetbreads, shallots, pomegranate and red wine), is complemented by an Omakase-style tasting menu called Carte Blanche.

This restaurant, situated halfway between the Estación Sur de Autobuses bus station and the Enrique Tierno Galván park, enthuses guests with its penchant for the historically inspired cooking of the city of Madrid. Chef Álex García de la Fuente has rediscovered and revived the city’s most historic recipes, bringing them up to date with his own personality. The à la carte, which features a section dedicated to tapas-style “bocados”, includes several dishes designed for sharing (the bocadillo de calamares with a citrus alioli – this is Madrid, after all!; the slightly spicy red prawns from Huelva “al ajillo”; smoked trout etc); plus the option of a tasting menu. The cocktails here, which have been renamed “aguaduchos” as a homage to the term used to describe the old kiosks in Spain that used to sell soft drinks, have a range of interesting names, such as Pichi, Chotis, Chulapo, etc.

This is indeed the same premises where chef Javier Estévez first opened what was to become the highly successful La Tasquería (the latter is now located in Calle Modesto Lafuente). It has retained the same look and bistro feel with a small kitchen overlooking the dining room, and offers guests cooking that is similar to that of the original La Tasquería but with a more informal menu of popular dishes. Of course, you’ll find tapas, raciones and dishes that feature its trademark offal (casquería in Spanish), plus a whole host of other non-related dishes. Don’t miss out on classics such as the tripe, trotter and snout, alongside options such as gildas, croquettes, prawns with garlic, quail eggs, and cannelloni with a trio of meats.

Haute cuisine in an exclusive setting? Here you can savour the culinary creations of renowned chef Ramón Freixa, who describes himself as Catalan but with a strong Madrid influence! With this luxurious establishment in the heart of the Salamanca district, the chef has taken a step further by diversifying his offering with two concepts that seek to satisfy different audiences. Atelier, a kind of clandestine speakeasy within the larger Tradición, has guests sit at a single U-shaped table, allowing the chef to come and go from the open kitchen and interact constantly with the customers (only 10 diners). Everything revolves around a single tasting menu called Origen (there is also a vegetarian option: Origen Vegetalia) which, based on truly top-quality produce, masterfully balances tradition and creativity, always serving dishes of the highest technical level. The bread service is particularly noteworthy, a heartfelt tribute to his parents and his roots!

At this restaurant (the original one still exists in Vilanova i la Geltrú), Brazilian-born chef Diego Ferreira is aiming to create a niche for himself in the Spanish capital. On the interior, with its hint of retro style, discover bold, approachable and unique cuisine that skilfully combines flavours with different provenances (Journey to Alaska, smoked eel bami noodles with soy, crispy temaki of nori seaweed, etc). The choice here is between the à la carte and several set menus.

In the heart of Chamberí, this elegant restaurant has been built on four solid pillars: personality, professionalism, hard work and an unbreakable will! The driving force behind the project is Rubén Hernández Mosquero, a globetrotting chef from Extremadura who has worked in some of the most prestigious establishments (Noma and Geranium in Copenhagen; Azurmendi in Larrabetzu; Il Ristorante at the Bvlgari Hotel Tokyo; Minibar by José Andrés in Washington; Atomix in New York...). EMi, a heartfelt tribute to his brother (Emilio, now deceased), has been devised as a haute cuisine bar for a maximum of 12 diners, with a fully open kitchen and a small private room overlooking the stoves. What's on offer? A single surprise menu where the chef puts his vast technical knowledge on display, with complex but balanced and delicate fusion dishes that reflect Nordic and Korean influences. There's even an extensive wine cellar with exclusive labels!

Set in a lovely building on a corner plot in the Prenzlauer Berg district, this restaurant has a clean-lined, modern look and a trio of industry professionals with a proven track record at the helm. Owner Silvio Pfeufer (formerly head chef at einsunternull) is in charge of the kitchen, co-owner and maître d' Janine Woltaire heads up the friendly service team – and here she has an experienced sommelier at her side in Michael Stiel – the pair were colleagues at Horváth, another Berlin restaurant. The two set menus (one of which is vegetarian) each comprise five or six courses. Alternatively, you can order from the à la carte selection. Diners are presented with a modern, ingredient-led take on traditional French cuisine, the "scallop, carrot, trout caviar" being a case in point. The name is a nod to the chef's grandfather, who once had a butcher's shop in this neighbourhood.

Restaurateur Björn Swanson, known on the Berlin food scene from faelt in the Schöneberg neighbourhood, brings his sophisticated yet accessible dining concept to SWAN&SON – "a modern bistro tale". Indeed, his dishes are modern and creative, combining classic and Japanese influences: think "black cod with sesame, spinach & soy beurre blanc" or "cordon bleu {tonkatsu style} with shiitake cream & cucumber salad". The space is all clean-lined chic; the terrace in front of the restaurant is lovely. At lunchtime, there is a somewhat simpler and more affordable offering.

Merold promises "new German cuisine" – top-notch regional ingredients from Berlin and Brandenburg served in the form of dishes such as "braised onion, buckwheat, black garlic" or "guinea fowl 'Backhendl', mashed potatoes, truffle remoulade". The dishes are often pared back to just a few components, which are perfectly prepared and combined. As a kind of signature dish, and an absolute must, the house-made bratwurst changes on a monthly basis, for instance, beef, sauerkraut and house-made doubanjiang. You can choose à la carte or opt for the four- or five-course set menu – with the fantastic bratwurst as an optional add-on. Their wine list is also well-stocked. The sleek modern interior is inviting, and the service is attentive, knowledgeable and agreeably relaxed. Chef-patron Jonas Merold himself frequently puts in an appearance front of house to greet diners and introduce his creations.

The elegant hotel Château Royal stands near the Brandenburg Gate, behind a dapper historical façade. Combining classical elements, design highlights and contemporary art in its impressively high-ceilinged rooms, it also houses a stylish restaurant with a lovely bar. The atmosphere is pleasingly intimate, and the cuisine bears the hallmarks of both Mediterranean and classic influences – the freshly made pasta is particularly popular. At lunchtime, the reasonably priced lunch set menu is a winner.

The centrepiece in this sleek, chic restaurant is the 1937 Cord 810/812 after which it is named. The choice to exhibit this car, which was the most advanced of its time, is no coincidence, as the restaurant is located on the future-oriented EUREF campus, a model district for climate protection, resource conservation and sustainability. The cuisine, based on select ingredients, is also of interest, with a good selection of modern dishes, including vegetarian and "Grill & Share" dishes, as well as Imperial caviar and a four-course signature menu. Conveniently, the S-Bahn is only a few minutes away.

This minimalist, urban-cool restaurant is located on Charlottenburg's bustling Kantstraße, known for its many restaurants. Itameshi – Japanese-Italian fusion cuisine – is the name of the game here. The surprise menu, dubbed "Omakase Italiano", comprises eight to 10 small plates presented in a pared-back, ingredient-led style, with fish and seafood taking centre stage. The best place to sit is at the long stainless steel counter, from which you can watch the chefs preparing and plating the dishes. Alternatively, you can take a seat at one of the small tables.

Owner Oliver Körber, who treats diners to authentic Berlin-style hospitality, and chef Ruben Pahl cook up a pleasingly unaffected gastro concept as a two-man operation. Located in a quiet side street between the small Viktoria-Luise-Platz, laid out in 1899, and the department store KaDeWe, the restaurant delivers a five-course set menu, plus two dishes as an optional extra. Just a handful of components go into the fantastic, classically based dishes. Delicious examples include the flavoursome lobster soup with vanilla radish or the perfectly cooked saddle of venison with a robust venison jus and Brussels sprouts. The attractive interior is quite minimalist, with interesting photographs of Berlin and New York (taken by Oliver Körber's daughter) adding a decorative element. There are only a few spots up for grabs each evening, so be sure to book in good time! In summer, make a beeline for the gorgeous little terrace!

The atmosphere here is friendly and vibrant, both on the terrace, with tables laid out on the street in front of the restaurant, and inside, where diners are seated at small tables (no tablecloths here), and old floorboards, panelled walls and a counter make for a traditional tavern-like atmosphere. The restaurant serves vegetarian Levante cuisine, including dishes that are perfect for sharing, such as hummus with roasted cauliflower or shakshuka. The delicious pita (flatbread) and the aromatic challah (yeast-leavened bread) come fresh from the oven – both can also be purchased to take home.

In this tiny – perhaps even the smallest – restaurant in Berlin, authentic sushi is served in a minimalist setting as an affordably priced omakase menu. The nigiri are the highlight: crafted with excellent ingredients and impressive skill by the owner, who prepares them right before your eyes and presents them himself from behind the simple wooden counter. There are three seatings: 1pm, 5pm and 8pm. N.B. The restaurant is somewhat hidden inside a building directly at Nordbahnhof that also houses an organic supermarket.

Sur la vivante place Gustave-Toudouze, ce bistrot parisien aux airs d’appartement seventies mêle béton ciré, velours orangé et œuvres d’art modernes dans une atmosphère branchée et chaleureuse. Le soir, les bougies scintillent derrière un rideau de lin, attisant la curiosité des passants. La carte ramassée fourmille d’idées bien balancées : maquereau de ligne flammé-salsa verde qui claque, tartelette échalote-moelle-comté qui réchauffe. Les incontournables vins nature sont bien sourcés, le service est cool et affûté. La salle est souvent pleine à craquer !

« Prévelle », un nom tout en douceur, comme la cuisine de Romain Meder. L’ancien complice d’Alain Ducasse y rend hommage à son enfance rurale, avec une partition végétale exclusivement francilienne, que viennent enrichir volailles, poissons et coquillages. Sa cuisine, moderne et résolument saisonnière, fait preuve d’une grande maîtrise technique : les assaisonnements ont du nerf, les cuissons de légumes se travaillent comme des viandes rôties, avec cette recherche des sucs et des arômes profonds issus de la réaction de Maillard, chère à son mentor. Après un passage devant la cuisine ouverte et sa table attenante, on grimpe à l’étage, où règnent le calme et la clarté d’un décor sobre et feutré.

Formé à L’Oustau de Baumanière et à L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon, Irwin Durand a affiné sa cuisine auprès d’Alan Geaam avant de rejoindre Guy Savoy (second à l'hôtel de la Monnaie de Paris, puis chef du Chiberta). À moins de 40 ans, il n’a pas perdu son temps. Son restaurant au cadre élégant et contemporain joue la carte de l’intimité : seulement 7 tables, ainsi qu'une table d'hôtes qui fait face à la cuisine ouverte. Soutenu par des talents féminins – la cheffe exécutive Camille Larquemin et la cheffe pâtissière Tessa Ponzo –, Irwin propose un menu mystère de saison. Les beaux produits du moment y reçoivent un vibrant hommage technique : maigre en ballotine dans l’esprit d’une grenobloise ; ris de veau à la moutarde de Meaux, petits pois et jus de veau réduit ; déclinaison de vanille et crémeux au miso...

À deux pas de la mairie de Montrouge, ce restaurant dont la terrasse s’anime aux beaux jours insuffle un vent nouveau à la gastronomie locale. Aux commandes, Cécile Farnier et Hélia Maouch, formées à Ferrandi, signent une carte courte et évolutive : effiloché de poisson à l’espuma de pomme de terre, poisson à la sauce vierge acidulée, dessert de saison rafraîchissant. Produits de qualité, cuissons justes, service souriant : une adresse vite adoptée par les habitués.

adresse: 48 rue de la Folie-Méricourt, Paris, 75011, France
description: Murs grattés, cuisine ouverte au fond, serveurs en mode cool : pas de doute, on est bien dans un spot qui fleure bon le 11e. La cheffe affirme une certaine idée de la tradition : volailles farcies, terrines et pâtés en croûte sont ici choyés sans réserve. Elle explore les cochonnailles de manière personnelle, à l'image de cette tatin de poire et boudin noir. Une cuisine gourmande et généreuse.

Jean-Pierre Vasseur a ouvert avec sa femme Jarlène une adresse de quartier chaleureuse à l’angle d’une rue résidentielle de sa ville natale. Passé par les maisons de Thierry Breton, il y propose une cuisine bistrotière aux accents bretons, sincère et généreuse. Velouté de potiron versé minute, andouille de Guémené et poitrine grillée à la purée beurrée, kouign amann aux pommes ou Paris-Brest-Paris en hommage à son ancien chef : des plats goûteux et bien faits dans un cadre simple mais vivant.

adresse: 112 rue de la Roquette, Paris, 75011, France
description: Après plusieurs expériences entre l’Australie et la France, le chef coréen Esu Lee ouvre son Jip – qui signifie "foyer" – , un minuscule restaurant à la décoration épurée, où l’on partage le comptoir au coude à coude. Il fait dialoguer la France et la Corée avec sensibilité : champignon eryngii au jalapeño et à la béarnaise ; mandu à la duxelles et gochujang ; ragoût de poulpe au sambal et sabayon de cébette. Cette cuisine d’auteur franco-coréenne reflète l’intelligence et la personnalité du chef.

À deux pas du marché d’Aligre, trois amis – Hugo, Thomas et Pierre, alias HuThoPi – sont à la tête de cette adresse de poche au décor brut et vivant : pierres apparentes, parquet, bocaux de légumes fermentés et cuisine ouverte. Passés par de belles maisons entre palaces et tables branchées (Le Meurice, Plaza Athénée, Oka, Cobéa, L’Ours…), ils proposent une cuisine d’esprit végétal, digeste et équilibrée, fondée sur les produits de saison : tomate Marmande et espuma piperade, crudo de sériole et ajoblanco, rouget barbet au sabayon safrané, cocos de Paimpol et lard de Colonnata.

Rive gauche, quai Voltaire : derrière une sobre façade noire, sans enseigne, simplement marquée du numéro 15, se dissimule l’un des temples parisiens du sushi. Masayoshi Hanada (ex-Sushi B) y orchestre un menu omakase unique, bâti autour de poissons d’exception – thon rouge méditerranéen, truite d’Auvergne, pêches bretonnes – travaillés avec une maîtrise absolue du geste et de la découpe. Une poignée de convives seulement prennent place au superbe comptoir en hinoki massif (le cyprès du Japon), face au ballet précis du chef et de ses assistants. Nigiris ciselés, makis, soupes et grillades au binchōtan s’enchaînent dans une vaisselle raffinée, entre tradition et design contemporain. Une courte carte de vins et de sakés parachève cette expérience rare et précieuse. Il est simplement demandé de ne pas prendre de photos pendant le repas.

You might, for a moment, feel as if you have stumbled across a wine cellar, but you will soon see that this hip South American eatery is very much at home in this cosmopolitan city. Nazka unleashes a whirlwind of bold flavours on your palate, from pisco cocktails to ceviche and other Peruvian specialities. This is exhilarating cuisine featuring a captivating interplay of spicy and sweet chilli peppers, Asian umami and the zing of leche del tigre. The well-curated selection of wines from around the globe adds extra character to this unique dining experience.

The clientele of this fashionable urban restaurant is a veritable of Vienna! The Italian cuisine served is modern and pared back, in keeping with the minimalist interior design – two good reasons to come here for a meal! Plump for one of the house classics such as fried calamari or vitello tonnato. Or perhaps you would prefer saffron risotto with Norway lobster? Friendly and attentive service, a large terrace in summer, and a bar that is ideal for a light bite or a pre-dinner drink.

Sam Van Landeghem a donné une nouvelle tournure au restaurant familial Michel. Cette villa élégante vous plonge dans une atmosphère conviviale, chaleureuse et accessible. La carte a été rajeunie, sans perdre son attention aux produits. Il associe ainsi des asperges belges al dente à des morilles, des fèves et un jus d’asperges. Ce chef aime les saveurs familières, mais n’hésite pas pour autant à introduire quelques délices asiatiques. La cuisine de marché de Gastro Brisk ne manque pas de peps !

Access to this elegant modern restaurant is via a cobbled courtyard. Inside, a warm colour scheme creates a pleasant atmosphere, and the front area features a light and airy winter garden. The classic cuisine with a Mediterranean touch is made with ingredients of the highest quality; example dishes include lobster soup or sea bass with white wine sauce. There are also different grilled dishes every day. Plus they have good wine recommendations up their sleeve.

adresse: 18-19 Parnell Square North, Rotunda, Dublin City, D01 T3V8, Irlande
description: Mickael Viljanen’s restaurant is a stylish, elegant spot decorated with eye-catching art, where superb service complements truly top-drawer cooking. Prime luxury ingredients – like Donegal lobster or Limousin sweetbreads – are the bedrock of the menu, prepared using classic French techniques combined with subtle modern touches. The chef’s creativity and personality shine through in perfectly balanced, immaculately executed dishes with sublime natural flavours and beautiful presentation. The 'Irish Coffee' is made in the dining room and is, like everything else, an experience to remember.

adresse: Church Road, Greystones, A63 TW18, Irlande
description: A welcome addition to this residential seaside town just south of Dublin, Caladh sits inside a double-fronted Georgian property painted in a fresh light green colour that permeates inside, giving a cool, calming vibe to the brasserie-style dining room. The chefs aren’t trying to reinvent the wheel here, and therein lies the appeal. Classic dishes like confit duck leg and grilled pork chop are ingredient-led and lean on the abundant natural flavours of the produce. A sensibly priced wine list adds to the already considerable attraction.

adresse: 4 Nassau Street, Dublin City, D02 YX74, Irlande
description: For a traditional taste of Ireland, you need look no further. Chef-Owner Stephen McAllister has dived deep into his grandmother's recipe book and centuries of Irish history for the latest incarnation of his welcoming restaurant, which occupies a tall and narrow townhouse overlooking Trinity College Park. The menu combines a love of classic, soul-warming cooking with a playful touch, resulting in dishes like "Boxty Pancake" and "Dublin Lawyer Lobster Omelette" – while the quality produce and careful execution are evident in full-flavoured options like the "Tongue 'n' Cheek Suet Pudding".

adresse: 58 Dorset Street Lower, Dublin 1, Dublin City, D01 EP86, Irlande
description: Forming part of JUNO, a larger red-brick pub where you can enjoy a pre-dinner Guinness, this bustling gastropub comes with wood panelling, soft lighting and a subtle elegance. Its menu has a pub-cooking base but is given some enticing international twists. Take the classic Scotch egg, for instance, which might come in a lamb and harissa form, or perhaps a chorizo version with preserved lemon and basil aioli. High-quality Irish ingredients, from Carlingford oysters to Achill lamb, underpin the dishes’ success. To finish, the brown butter and miso tart is a real treat.

adresse: 8/9 Sussex Terrace, Ranelagh, Dublin City, D04 KN82, Irlande
description: When you browse a menu and see words like ‘pâté’, ‘rillettes’, ‘vin jaune’ and ‘au poivre’, you know you’re in for a thoroughly French treat. The surprise at Forêt is that these Francophone delights are found above the M. O’Brien’s pub – which couldn’t sound more Irish if it tried. Nevertheless, thanks to the team behind Forest Avenue next door, here you have a delicious slice of France, with every authentic dish combining top-quality produce and skilled execution to flavour-packed effect. The tomato tart with piperade is a prime example, simply bursting with umami.

adresse: 1 Windsor Terrace, Portobello, Dublin City, D08 HT20, Irlande
description: There’s so much going for this neighbourhood Italian restaurant in the Portobello district of Dublin. For one, its immense popularity means there’s a brilliant buzz to the place; add to that its canalside setting and appealingly simple interior, and the stage is set for a terrific night out. Start with a glass from their well-chosen list of fine Italian wines, before diving into the roll-call of classic dishes. The ossobuco with risotto Milanese is a good choice, as is the light and well-balanced tiramisu. The friendly team manage the busy room with aplomb.

adresse: 4 Harry Street, Dublin City, D02 CX24, Irlande
description: Describing itself as ‘Brazilian Roots in Irish Soil’, this hidden-away restaurant offers something different to the Dublin dining scene. Set on the first floor of a former shoe shop, you ring the doorbell by the plain black door to enter, before being whisked up into the dining room. Foliage hangs from the ceiling, while a drawing of a favela pays homage to where Chef Viktor Silva grew up; the restaurant’s name, Amai, is a tribute to the women who raised him. The tasting menu fuses Irish produce with South American flavours in dishes that are packed with interesting flavours and textures.

adresse: 3 Joshua Lane, Dublin City, D02 C856, Irlande
description: Something of a hidden gem tucked away in the city centre, this wood-panelled restaurant has a simple, intimate appeal. The compact space is run with great skill by the experienced service team, while the chefs prepare dishes pulling influences from both the Mediterranean and closer to home. Dishes often shine at their simplest, like a bowl of plump baby tomatoes in their own juices, and it’s a good idea to start with sharing snacks like the robustly flavoured liver parfait with fermented blood orange. It’s a popular place, so you can expect a good buzz in the room.

adresse: 162-165 Phibsborough Road, Dublin City, D07 RX3P, Irlande
description: Transplanting the Italian osteria to the Irish capital, this former bank has no trouble filling its large space with an almighty buzz from the many happy diners feasting on its simply delicious cooking. The enticing menu ranges from sourdough pizzette to homemade pastas and a wood-fired section showcasing prime fish and meat. The generous, well-priced plates have an honest simplicity to them, with recognisable dishes cooked with skill and packing in plenty of flavour. For dessert, consider the polenta cake with seasonal fruit.

adresse: 30 Brunswick Street North, Stoneybatter, Dublin City, D07 TP64, Irlande
description: You can’t help but fall for this rustic little restaurant and its warm, welcoming young team. Dark green walls and dried flowers are indicative of the nature-focused approach, with seasonal produce and a low-waste ethos key to its charms. In the day it’s a simple café serving particularly good coffee and viennoiserie, before the kitchen steps up a gear in the evening with cooking that is a feast for the eyes and the taste buds. Influences from across the globe are poured into the flavour-packed dishes, like an original venison fattoush salad with baba ganoush.

This attractive restaurant is accommodated in a spruce historical house. The elegant modern interior, high ceilings and large, floor-to-ceiling windows make for a pleasing, airy feel. The open kitchen in the middle turns out contemporary Italian dishes – highlights include the fish and meat cooked on the oven grill. The excellent pasta is also a tempting option. Attentive and experienced service rounds off your dining experience.

This restaurant tucked away in the basement of a residential building is done out in a bright and minimalist modern style. As the name suggests, the cuisine is Japanese. In addition to classic hot dishes, there is a good selection of sushi and sashimi. To go with your food, there is sake and whisky from Japan.

There are many reasons to visit this restaurant in the elegant Four Seasons Hotel: the charming location by the Vltava River, the chic ambience, the beautiful large bar and the terrace overlooking the river… And, of course, the Italian cuisine with a modern twist. Dishes such as vitello tonnato, house-made pasta, fresh sea bass or duck breast show off the exquisite quality of the ingredients.

In his charming little restaurant, Jan Kracík serves food inspired by classic French cuisine and the culinary experiences he made during his years of travelling. Dishes such as veal sweetbreads with morels in sauce à la crème, or fillet of seabass with shallots and white wine sauce are available à la carte and as part of the "Menu Pot-au-Feu" or "Menu of the Season" (with options for each course). There are also a few daily specials. The welcoming atmosphere is enhanced by the friendly and laid-back, yet dedicated and knowledgeable front-of-house team, as well as a cosy modern decor with wine racks and art as decorative details.

The atmosphere here is trendy and lively with a friendly neighbourhood vibe. You'll enjoy an Asian-inspired cuisine, served by friendly staff – the "Beef smoked red curry: homemade sausage, pastrami & braised shin, spiced potatoes & fried shallots" is a tempting option, for example. Importance is placed on regional and seasonal ingredients, organic whenever possible. You can choose dishes à la carte or go for one of the set menus, which come in classic or vegetarian options. The affordable lunch set menu is particularly enticing.

Ten seats are set around a horseshoe counter, chefs interact with guests, presenting carefully executed, boldly flavoured dishes, which are inspired by the Czech cuisine using only local products. The tasting experience starts at a fixed time in the evening, beginning with an introduction to the region's seasonal products staged in eight to ten courses. Wine pairings are offered to match.

Good food and warm hospitality await in this 1905 townhouse located near the Vltava River and Kinský Garden. The enthusiasm of the team is palpable. The cosy, somewhat shabby-chic decor and the extremely dedicated, friendly and courteous front-of-house team make for a wonderful atmosphere. The food is cooked with respect for tradition, but also with a modern twist. In the morning, everything revolves around breakfast, but in the evening, the five-course set menu takes centre stage – think mouthwatering dishes such as beef cheeks with rose hip, cranberry and truffle, or the classic Bohemian sour soup.

If you want to experience authentic Georgian cuisine, this restaurant in a commercial building just a few metres from the Vltava River is the place for you. Be sure to sample the classic khinkali, available with various fillings – they are second to none! The barbecued dishes, which are also packed with flavour, come accompanied by typical sauces. The setting is wonderfully spacious and cheerful: it features decorative elements such as traditional colourful pendant lamps and patterned fabrics. Live Georgian music adds to the atmosphere.

Located directly opposite its parent establishment, Café Imperial, this restaurant boasts an elegant blend of modern and classical aesthetics. In a stylish and invitingly vibrant setting, a highly competent and well-organised team provides attentive service. To the rear of the dining space you can see the chefs crafting classic dishes in the open kitchen: braised beef with a creamy sauce and bread dumplings, or sautéed rabbit kidneys with mustard sauce – the extensive menu has something to offer every palate! Breakfast is also available, and the restaurant remains open continuously throughout the day.

Old Boy se définit comme un restaurant de grillades de l’Asie du Sud-Est. Concrètement, on y trouve des produits belges, issus notamment du Monde des mille couleurs et de Dierendonck, étincelants dans une cuisine fusion entre Bangkok, la Thaïlande et la Chine. L’ambiance « streetfood » enflammée et le côté piquant maîtrisé sont bien présents. Un filet de canard grillé prend une autre dimension grâce à une sauce au curry vert au lait de coco et au basilic thaïlandais. Une cuisine sans complications qui ne manque pas de peps. Le cadre tendance apporte une touche de fraîcheur, tout comme la belle sélection de vins naturels et la carte attrayante. N’oubliez pas de réserver, le soir !

Au dernier étage de l’hôtel-boutique Faubourg 21, venez vous immerger dans un univers de luxe. L’architecte d’intérieur Sarah Lavoine a créé un décor personnel et sobre où se distinguent les matériaux de choix comme le marbre et la porcelaine. La vue sur le parc de Bruxelles est superbe. Dès votre entrée, le personnel est aux petits soins. Kevin Lejeune privilégie, lui aussi, l’excellence. Ce chef aguerri au bagage solide, travaille de façon détaillée et donne à chaque plat une tournure unique, avec des saveurs prononcées. Il cuit ainsi le saint-pierre avec du kombu, accompagné d’une crème d’algues. Il associe un veau de lait de Corrèze à un jus de cuisson intense et des accompagnements méditerranéens tels qu’une riche crème de vieux parmesan. Chez Chaga, rien n’est laissé au hasard.

adresse: Chemin des Deux Fermes 5, Rosières, 1331, Belgique
description: Màloma est l’enseigne culinaire de Foster, écosystème éco-responsable pour les artisans, les fermiers et les entreprises. Le respect de l’environnement déploie toutes ses facettes. Le restaurant lumineux et élégamment décoré de Georges Athanassopoulos porte son attention sur les produits, principalement les légumes et les fruits, avec çà et là un morceau de viande ou de poisson. Il laisse s’exprimer leurs saveurs, sous des formes variées, parfois complexes, mais l’intensité des saveurs est toujours au rendez-vous. Il fourre ainsi une fleur de citrouille d’une farce subtile de volaille, qu’il frit dans une croûte de tempura croustillante. Une tomate grillée y ajoute une belle intensité, tandis qu’une crème de feta lui offre une touche épicée. Un hommage coloré et vivifiant à la saison !

Oltra fait référence à l’ancien nom latin du village Outer. Ce restaurant vous accueillera dans une ambiance conviviale et un cadre chargé d’histoire. Les ornements campagnards, comme les carreaux de pierre provenant d’une église et le fer forgé soulignent cette atmosphère agréable. Une jeune équipe est aux manettes. Iwert assure un service attentionné et prodigue ses conseils œnologiques, tandis que le chef Jonathan met sa créativité au service de la cuisine française. Il s’appuie sur des saveurs telles que la citronnelle ou le vinaigre pour élaborer des assiettes regorgeant de fraîcheur. Il associe ainsi des structures de tomate et des olives vertes à l’umami de crevettes de la mer du Nord, une glace au raifort pour une touche épicée et un jus de tomate et verveine. Une affaire de passion, c’est une évidence.

Voilà un lieu qui sort de l’ordinaire. Situé au chemin du Crabbegat, dans le plus ancien édifice d’Uccle, ce restaurant quelque peu mystérieux mêle les éléments anciens, comme le plafond en bois et le vieux poêle, avec une décoration chinoise subtile. Vous y trouverez des délices traditionnels révélant leurs multiples facettes dans des plats colorés et généreux. Un succulent rouleau de printemps fourré de volaille et d’oignon caramélisé, des nouilles sautées avec des légumes croustillants, un excellent canard à la pékinoise... Une authenticité qui donne l’eau à la bouche, rassemblée dans une carte aussi variée qu’irrésistible.

adresse: Rue de la Crêche 11, Ixelles, 1050, Belgique
description: Le nom de cette osteria familiale en dit long sur les sentiments qu’elle suscite. Avec Giuseppe et Karina en cuisine, ainsi que Kevin en salle, vous serez entre les mains d’une équipe passionnée. Commencez par quelques savoureux antipasti, comme ce subtil carpaccio de bœuf avec une vinaigrette acidulée et des copeaux de parmesan. Vous pourrez poursuivre avec des pâtes maison, par exemple des tagliatelles al dente et un ragoût intense. Et que diriez-vous d’une généreuse préparation de tagliata d’entrecôte Angus ? L’assiette regorge d’une passion pour l’Italie. Sans chichis inutiles, avec un accent sur les saveurs authentiques et familières. Une maison de confiance !

« On boit un flacon ? » est une phrase qui revient comme un leitmotiv lorsque Pierre Guérin et ses amis se rencontrent. L’idée de déguster un bon verre en bonne compagnie est aussi le motif central de cet agréable bistrot. Le chef y ajoute une cuisine bistronomique décontractée, déclinée dans une excellente formule le midi et à la carte le soir. Une cuisine soignée, attentive au produit et qui va droit au but. Il intensifie ainsi une préparation de pâte feuilletée croustillante de porc, d’épinards et de pourpier avec un jus de cuisson au vin rouge et de la moutarde en grains, un mélange d’épices, du vin rouge et des pois chiches. Loin des associations complexes, on y déguste des saveurs intenses et reconnaissables.

Le père et le beau-fils en cuisine, la mère et la fille en salle : Mariette est un véritable établissement familial. Le restaurant respire l’élégance, et dispose d’une jolie terrasse au jardin. La cuisine franco-belge, avec quelques touches internationales, domine la carte variée, et peut être aisément partagée. On est d’emblée frappé par la qualité des produits, comme le turbot ou les noix de Saint-Jacques. Les chefs cuisent le faisan juteux et le servent avec des chicons légèrement caramélisés, des croquettes roulées à la main et une sauce fine champagne. Un restaurant chaleureux et authentique.

Deux copains, Michael et Niels, accueillent leurs hôtes dans cet agréable restaurant convivial au cœur de Dilbeek, avec une belle terrasse au jardin. Ils font tout à eux deux et partagent une grande passion pour les produits. Les légumes de la ferme locale, le poisson venu tout droit de la mer du Nord : ils savent dénicher les meilleurs produits, qu’ils cuisinent sans complexes, avec quelques touches de créativité, comme ces textures surprenantes et ces saveurs fermentées toniques. Ils cuisinent ainsi

This relaxed and friendly, modern restaurant is very popular with locals, and no wonder given the delicious fare on offer. Menu options include chanterelle terrine with walnuts, lamb’s lettuce and bresaola as well as Viennese specialities such as veal lights and Black Angus rib-eye steak. The terrace looks onto the pedestrian zone.

Close to the Mariahilfer Straße shopping drag, on the seventh floor of the chic MOTTO boutique hotel, this restaurant has really distinctive architecture. The tasteful upscale interior will appeal to diners, as will the pleasantly lounge-like atmosphere. Be sure to check out the interesting bar too. The food is uncomplicated and unpretentious. Try the bouillabaisse – one of the classics! – and don't forgo the apricot dumplings. One floor up is the rooftop terrace, which boasts a magnificent view, and, although it only serves a smaller menu, is nonetheless the place to be!

This small restaurant with six tables is housed in what used to be a coffee house – the sign outside simply reads "K". They serve a six-course set menu made using seasonal ingredients, into which chef Daniel Horner (previously sous-chef at Japanese restaurant Mochi) and his team cleverly incorporates the odd subtle Asian flavour. Drawing on a selection of Austrian and international wines, sommelier Vanessa Schober recommends pairings for the set menu. Non-alcoholic tea accompaniments are also available. Diners can alternatively opt for a shortened tasting menu comprising just four courses. The cheerful, modern decor has an urban feel. You can also take in temporary art exhibitions here – the proprietor owns a gallery.

The setting alone is a huge draw: the first floor of a 1901 Jugendstil building in a super-central location. The interior decor is at once elegant yet cosy, and the front-of-house team is experienced and pleasingly laid back, while operating in the classical style, like a well-oiled machine. And, of course, there is the exceptional food: a celebration of Viennese classics, elevated by creative seasonal additions. There is a well-curated à la carte selection with a set menu option – diners are spoilt for choice, with dishes such as the rustic hand-carved ham being just as tempting as the oven-baked pike-perch with a ginger and citrus butter.

A cool concept that attracts guests all day long. On Fridays, they serve up a cosy breakfast; Saturday is "Rosi Brunch Club" with a menu that changes every week; on Thursdays and Fridays, there is an affordable lunchtime daily special. In the evening from Wednesday to Saturday, sharing is the name of the game. The interesting menu includes a surprise "Chef's Choice" (if ordered by the whole table); otherwise, you can make your own choice of delicious dishes and share them – the spotlight is on vegetarian dishes. The food is as unfussy as the relaxed and lively atmosphere that reigns in the restaurant, which is done out in a charming minimalist style.

There is only space for a handful of diners at the L-shaped chef's table in this restaurant's minimalist dining space. A nine-course set menu is prepared in the fully open stainless steel kitchen – this culinary journey through Korea lasts approximately three hours. Authenticity is key, but local ingredients and European cooking techniques still find their place. This results in intensely flavoursome dishes such as "gochujang ceviche": slices of Austrian trout marinated in chilli paste, topped with a tangy grapefruit sabayon and finished with a delicate basil oil. The service is charming and attentive to every guest's needs and enjoys sharing insights into the finer points of Korean cuisine.

Jola takes its name from the charming duo behind this venture: Jonathan Wittenbrink, who delivers outstanding vegan cuisine, and Larissa Andres, who manages the service in the compact dining space with charm and aplomb. Seasonal and regional ingredients go into the creative surprise set menu, which features memorable dishes such as raviolo stuffed with aubergine ragout, served with courgette, lightly toasted pine nuts and a wonderfully intense tomato essence. Choose between wine and alcohol-free pairings. The setting is stylish and modern yet pleasingly laid back – the open kitchen certainly adds to that. A nice touch: The menu is printed on plantable seed paper – take it home and see what blooms!

This charming and trendy restaurant is located in the heart of Vienna's vibrant Spittelberg neighbourhood, known for its bars, restaurants and shops. The centrepiece is the large counter and open kitchen, where unfussy seasonal dishes are prepared. The ingredients are exclusively Austrian, mostly organic goods sourced from trusted suppliers. The house speciality is game, which the chefs also hunt themselves. Dishes include venison carpaccio with pickled celeriac and celeriac mayonnaise, and game schnitzel with potato salad and lemon. The exceptionally friendly and attentive team serves either a five-course tasting menu or individual dishes à la carte. During summer, the rain-protected pergola, with its open front of windows, provides a terrace-like setting. N.B. Parking in the immediate vicinity is difficult, but the nearest underground station, Volkstheater, is only a few minutes' walk away.

Like its MICHELIN-starred sister restaurant, this bistro serves excellent vegetarian/vegan food, with a commitment to a responsible, seasonal and local concept, as well as an emphasis on organic and Demeter-certified produce. Creations such as "TIAN Tatar, Joseph Bread", "Kohrabi, Elderflower, Pea" and "Risotto, Chanterelles, Fennel" stand out on account of their select regional ingredients and have all the qualities of signature dishes. Designed for sharing, the set menu is very reasonably priced. The location is in the heart of the lively Spittelberg neighbourhood, which is teeming with places to eat and drink. Inside, the atmosphere is vibrant, and the minimalist, clean-lined interior reflects a deep-rooted affinity with nature. Gorgeous covered courtyard.

The spicy aromas hit you the moment you enter this colonial-era building dating from 1899. An abundance of wood and an exotic colour scheme make for a uniquely charming setting inside – this place calls itself a café because of its casual atmosphere. The home-style Indonesian cuisine, with a slight preference for Balinese specialities, is indulgent and packs a punch. Think aromatic martabak, rich authentic (including vegetarian options) with spicy rendang and intensely flavoursome sambal goreng telor… At Café Samabe, a feast awaits!

De Kas has grown steadily since it was established in 2001 and has now reached maturity. "From plant to plate" has always been the motto here, a vision of sustainability that seemed a tall order at the outset. But the team persevered and today are a standard-bearer of the MICHELIN Green Star. They grow about 300 varieties of vegetables, herbs and fruit both on site and in their larger field in the Beemster Polder. What is harvested in the morning from the imposing greenhouse will take pride of place on the plate a little later, in light, modern creations. Tip: make a beeline for the fabulous garden terrace. Wim de Beer and Jos Timmer are masters in the art of delicately balancing sweet and sour flavours. Subtle sauces highlight the creative vegetable dishes (sometimes with meat or fish). For example, a soft saffron cream elevates the smoky flavour of barbecued pointed cabbage, and the briny freshness of cockles is accentuated by a lime leaf emulsion. The wealth of natural produce that these chefs have at their disposal is a constant source of inspiration for their seemingly boundless creativity, and that is what foodies really revel in.

Bold graffiti art and a dark palette of black and red create an intimate and laid-back feel. In the kitchen, the cuisines of Japan, China, Thailand and Indonesia artfully rub shoulders. The chef always manages to dose just the right spices, creating dishes full of rich flavours and crisp textures. Whether you opt for sushi, dim sum, Peking duck or sea bass with panang curry, this Asian culinary adventure puts authenticity front and centre.

adresse: Simon van Capelweg 10, Noorden, 2431 AG, Pays-Bas
description: The drive alongside the canals affords a foretaste of what awaits at this refurbished restaurant: the views over the water are simply sublime. Inside the tastefully appointed country house, diners are warmly received by a highly attentive and professional team. The chef unites classic cooking methods and generosity with modern textural elements to create dishes that are balanced and wide-ranging. Take, for example, his refined starter of salmon mousse, herb vinaigrette, ripe olives and pickled cucumber. Be sure to enquire about overnight stays and boat trips (with a picnic basket) on the Nieuwkoopse Plassen.

This quintessential bistro serves classics of the genre, such as an indulgent take on with an onion and red wine confit, barbecued baby chicken presented on vintage tableware, profiteroles stuffed with vanilla ice cream and an intense chocolate sauce – every dish is artfully composed. In its wallet-friendly à la carte and prix-fixe menus, there are plenty of tempting options, and the same goes for the expertly curated selection of French wines – Jan is the man to ask for recommendations. The decor is simply enchanting with its copper pans, elegant glass wine cabinet and undeniable .

Foer certainly has character both in terms of the stylish decor – nab a place at the dining counter if you can – and the food. The focus here is on vegetables and herbs, perhaps complemented by a fish or meat dish. Using inventive preparation techniques, Steven Broere succeeds in elevating vegetables in original combinations. For instance, he marries intense beetroot cooked in a salt crust and an emulsion of egg yolk with subtle acidity to create a remarkable flavour sensation. The select wines add to this unique sense of harmony.

Bistrôt Chapeau exudes French elegance: white tablecloths, warm tones, typical chansons playing in the background and a terrace where you can relax. Chef Nicky Quarz cooks here with classic precision and a penchant for dishes that are too often forgotten. No frills and full of flavour. Think homemade wild boar pâté with lively garnishes that provide a nice counterbalance, or juicy guinea fowl stuffed with tartufata and served with soft pommes fondantes and a creamy mushroom sauce, among other things. This cuisine remains true to its roots. And more good news: the full menu is also available for lunch.

Bistro Toost – un restaurant du Guide MICHELIN Pays-Bas 2025. Les avis des inspecteurs MICHELIN, des informations sur les prix, le type de cuisine et les horaires d'ouverture sur le site officiel du Guide MICHELIN

Dennis Huwaë is renowned for his work at MICHELIN-starred Daalder but also appreciates the simplicity of classic bistro cuisine. And this is abundantly clear at his elegantly furnished restaurant on a corner plot in the heart of the Jordaan neighbourhood. A relaxed atmosphere reigns in the warmly lit interior. Choose between a table or a spot at the marble counter, then kick things off with a freshly shaken cocktail as you peruse the frequently updated menu. Start with oysters or caviar on toast, then move on to chopped lobster tail and razor clams paired with creamy orzo and crisp vegetable accoutrements. Alluring bistro flavours and refreshing modern touches breathe life into every dish at this hip gastrobar!
